title: Why did the Vikings hate the Christians so much and single them out for the most vicious atrocities? - Quora

response.answer_text: There’s a tradition that someone asked famous criminal Willie Sutton why he robbed banks and he replied, “Because that’s where the money is.” The saying may not be true, but it’s become known as Sutton’s Law. Similarly, the Vikings seem to have targeted monasteries because that was where the valuables were—nothing personal. in my studies on English history and Old or Middle English chronicles and literature, the English consider the Vikings as savages and sometimes attribute them to divine punishment, but I’m not aware of the Vikings having any fundamental hatred for Christians. Even in the saint’s lives stories where priests are killed, the Vikings are interested in fast loot and female Irish slaves to kidnap. In Aelfric’s life of St. Edmund the Vikings are “pagans,” and they chop King Edmund’s head off because he won’t submit and pay them—they don’t particularly care about his faith. Remember also that when the Vikings finally stayed in northeastern England, they became Christians, and some were already.

I don’t think at first they singled them out - Christians just happened to concentrate their gold in monasteries full of unarmed, non-martial men. From a viking perspective this was incredibly foolish (and probably somewhat confusing), but they took advantage of it while they could. When they could no longer do so, many vikings (like Rollo in Normandy) converted to Christianity to better solidify their monarchical claims or engage in diplomacy with Catholic rulers. At this point, some Norse individuals surely hated Christians a great deal, for essentially ‘conquering’ their leaders culturally without beating them in battle. Imagine how frustrating to spend decades or even centuries winning battles and pillaging people, only to have your leaders abandon the gods who gave you so much victory and adopt the God of the same people you’ve been pillaging!
